The cells of Clostridium mediterraneense are typically rod-shaped and can form terminal or subterminal endospores. The ecological role and potential biotechnological applications of Clostridium mediterraneense are still under investigation, as further research is needed to fully understand its physiological capabilities and environmental adaptations.
